reviewText:
Really enjoyable game, and I love that it allows you to play at your own pace. If you want to sell 10 different complicated but high priced pizzas at the same time, you can - there's nothing stopping you from customizing your pizza whatever way you want to. If you want a relaxing experience or just to tune out for a few minutes and let your brain relax, just serve a few kinds of simple pizzas for a few in-game hours.

If you want, you can even set how long the in-game workday lasts. If you want an intense challenge, set an 8-hour work day (1 in-game hour is roughly 1 minute, I think) and have 20 pizzas on your menu at the same time, I tell you, you'll need to take a minute to relax after finishing.

But the management aspect of the game is the best part in my opinion. There are so many customization options and upgrades and the game is balanced so well that progression is logical and based on the player's skill level. With one exception (that I encountered, at least, I know there's multiple storyline paths) in the main storyline where I was forced to play for pure profit for a bit, I never felt like the game was getting too hard or too easy. Or even that it imposed a certain gameplay style on me, like Cook, Serve, Delicious, the closest example I can give, did with the increasing number of lanes" - in Pizza Express
date: you can even influence the range of people you'll have to serve in a day.\n\nThe graphics are quite enjoyable
recommended: they reminded me of Pizza Tycoon

reviewText:
Simple, yet fun game with an incredible emphasis on customization.
Seriously - you can customize literally everything you can possibly think of: from basic stuff like yor restaurant's menu to the table's disposition and working hours!

reviewText:
Well what could I say about Pizza Express? At first sight you may think that it is a short game with some limitations, but in reality it's a full-fledged experience. It's a simple. yet effective and challenging managerial game where you run an 8-bit restaurant and make delicious 8-bit Pizza for the hungry 8-bit people!

PROS+ Managerial game at its finest - you can make your own Pizza by adding any ingredients you want, upgrade your restaurant in different ways and manage advertising.
+ Storyline with some choices to make and well-written dialogues.
+ Challenging gameplay with different difficulty levels.
+ Amazing 8-bit graphics and soundtrack.

CONS- Tutorials can be a bit too long.

Personal rating: 80/100
Got this one gifted by a friend of mine, but I'd say it is worth it at full-price considering how long it takes to beat, and remember to grow a moustache for the full experience!

reviewText: A really addicting game, that gets you hooked up to the story and the characters sooner than you'd like to admit ;). The gameplay itself is simple yet customizable in so many ways you'll never get bored of it. The different choices you can take along the story makes it feel almost like a visual novel, however as soon as the restaurant opens you're immediately put in action, which is a positive thing for me considering I'm not really fond of novels/reading in general.\nThe only negative thing I really NEED to point out is that as soon as you'll close the game you might transform in some pizza-starved monster that will not rest until its hunger is satisfied, talking from personal experience here so be careful.

reviewText:
One-Sentence SummaryA retro-styled management sim plus arcade hybrid with a story campaign which is lovingly crafted, endlessly customizable, and overflowing with charming details and atmosphere.

Pros+ Fun, enjoyable dialogue and characters
+ Charming retro graphics and visual design
+ Surprisingly deep gameplay customizations
+ Addictive one-more-turn pacing
+ Very polished; great attention to little details
+ Developer's passion reflected in his work
+ Makes you hungry for pizza

Cons- Tutorial is overly wordy at times
- May cause eye-strain due to no graphics filters
- Serious risk of carpal tunnel syndrome

Final ThoughtsIf Papers Please, Pizza Tycoon, and Cook, Serve, Delicious had a menage-a-trois, Pizza Express would be their adorable love child.  My hats off to Onni Interactive for their obvious passion and work on this game.  It is truly a diamond in the rough and I look forward to seeing what they come up with next.

Addressing the cons: some sort of scanline interlace filter may help with some of the issues I had with eyestrain while playing the game, and perhaps an option to assign hotkeys to ingredients could help with hand cramps due to excessive mouse handling.  My workaround for these two issues was to play in windowed mode and dial the resolution way down so mouse drag distance was reduced and text became more condensed and easier to read.

reviewText:
Very fun, interesting, simple yet challenging game! It has a neat story, filled with amusing characters, plots and many more things. Here are some of the pro's and con's I can think of:

Pro's
Stunning 8bit graphics
Interesting and ongoing story, which is going to keep you entertained for hours
Filled with joyful music (even if you don't like it, you can import your own music!)
A high detailed tutorial, explaining everything you need to know
Customizable work shift (you decide how painful and hard you want the game to be)
Customizable pizza menu, huge list of ingridients
Lots of other things such as deciding how you want to advertise your pizzeria, deciding how you want to award your customers (with discounts) and you can change the atmosphere.
Works great on fullscreen and with multiple screens
Con's
Tutorials take time but once you are done with them its okay.
Can't really think of any more con's, if I will find anything, I will edit the review.
Highly recommended.
10/10

reviewText:
Hilarious restaurant management sim! This funny 8bit pizza restaurant management game is a little gem at a totally fair price. If you enjoyed Cook, Serve, Delicious, you will for sure enjoy this game.

The core gameplay revolves around making pizzas by combining the correct ingredients. The staple customer patience (like in Diner Dash) will of course affect the performance of your pizzamaking. Contrary to CSD, which has a very limited management part, Pizza Express has a generous ingredients and furniture catalog which will appease the crowd which also wants a pure management part.

All in all, a great, fun, restaurant sim!
voteText: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
An incredibly fun and addicting game for anyone who is into cooking games, or tycoons/simulators.
Here's a gameplay & review video that showcases all the features I'm going to talk about
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L-Dr4YYwoIg
Pizza express gives you control over so many aspects that come with running a restaurant business. The details are what make the game so satisfying to play.

You choose open and close times for the restaurant, cater to vegans and lactose-intolerant customers by creating pizzas with your own chosen ingredients, and purchase different types of advertisements that have different effects. For example,  you can spam people's email inboxes for a cheap price, but it is frowned upon and won't be as effective as a giant billboard by the road.

Although going into the game I wasn't expecting to be introduced to characters or story, they're actually very well written, engaging and fun to go along with. You have choices that branch the story's path, which makes the game even more interesting.

Going back to the level of control the game gives you, bankruptcy is a thing that can happen in this game. If you aren't careful, and buy more ingredients, give out too many free drinks, and make too many mistakes, you CAN run out of money. If you're careful, it won't ever happen, but it's nice to know that your choices matter.

There's so much to talk about, but I really think if you like the sound of what I've already mentioned, then you should give the game a try. One of my top 2 cooking/restaurant running games I've ever played.

Enjoy!

reviewText:
I'm 7+ hours into this game and still enjoying it immensely. Its pixely graphics may lead the casual browser to perceive that it is a bit of a cheap game and will perhaps not have much that's satisfying to offer, but don't let the appearance fool you: this is one of the best business simulation games on Steam! I am very surprised at its depth.

There are essentially two phases: day (open hours) and night (closed hours).

During open hours, customers will flood into the store, order pizzas off of your menu, and then wait for you to make them. In this part you'll be playing something akin to cook
recommended: delicious" where you actually have to assemble the pizza from your batch of ingredients and then send it out to the customers. You dont' want to keep the customers waiting too long
hoursPlayed: so you have to build the pizzas quickly and accurately. One thing that potential players may NOT like about this section is that you can't just assemble the pizzas using hotkeys
voteText: like you can do in "cook

column17: you are in for a treat.\n\nThe real surprise with this game is how robust the business sim elements are during closed hours. The longer you play
column18: the more features start to unlock. You get to order your pizza shop's inventory of ingredients from a large catalogue to give your shop a flavor you like (while taking into consideration the needs of different customers
column22: etc). There are more ingredients in the catalogue than you can possibly have in your shop
column23: so there is some choice to consider. The game tells you the "stats" for each ingredient as well
column24: as far as how it will alter the flavor of the pizza and/or what kind of customer taste it will please (e.g. sweet
column29: etc).\n\nIn addition to stocking your own ingredients
column32: and price each specific pizza on your menu. This part actually takes a lot of management

column35: then determine how much you want to charge for it. I found that charging about 180% of the pizza's ingredient cost does not make the customers unhappy and still earns you a good profit. For complex pizzas anyway. For simpler pizzas

You'll want to strike a good balance of super easy pizzas (fast but low profit) and complicated pizzas (slow but more profit). It's also good to try and evenly distribute each individual ingredient across pizzas. For example

reviewText:
This is a great game. Ok, it looks terrible, and it's full of talking animals. But it's actually really good.

In this game, you run a pizzeria. It's an authentic Italian pizzeria, so that's cool - don't go in expecting all donner / tandoori meat pizzas with garlic bread and fries. Expect Italian ingredients, and choice of about a dozen types of cheese.

You choose the names and what's going to be on the pizzas, the quality and quantity of each of the ingredients (each ingredient has taste ratings, e.g. how salty or sweet etc - so you can really balance a pizza), and the pricing, then each in-game day you'll be taking customer orders and making those pizzas. That bit's all fast-paced dragging and dropping.

You also get to control advertising, furniture, services (e.g. free customer wi-fi) and there's an overall story which is pretty funny.

The overall effect of having complete control over your naming and creation of each pizza is that every creation is your own doing - and in turn, you are in control of the game's difficulty. If you want to give your pizzas weird names where you're going to have to slow yourself down by looking up what's on it each time someone asks for one, it's your own fault. If you want to advertise to get more people through the door before you've bought enough tables to seat them all so they get impatient and leave, it's your own fault. But it's all ok, you will learn by doing.

Also, if all the business management and story is too much, you unlock arcade mode after a while where it's purely the pizza-making portion of the game.

So - to summarise:

Pros:
* lots of detailed customisation in shop management
* fun arcade gameplay, as challenging as you choose to make it
* interesting story and characters
* funny dialogue
* I really like the chiptune music

Cons:
* having all these animals in the kitchen feels kind of unsanitary
* the user interface is a bit dodgy in places
* the graphics are pretty ugly

reviewText: Extremely detailed and expansive management sim + tense, reflex-testing pizza-making marathons. It manages to feel both very fun and very tiring. Honestly, this game feels like hard work! With the stakes being raised each business day, you feel a constant pressure to do more, better, faster or lose everything. With the stress comes great relief and a sense of accomplishment from surviving another throng of customers. Best in short bursts but has enough content to keep you playing for a long time.

reviewText: I’ve never been one for sim games, so the fact that this is on my list should mean something right away. Also, in full disclosure, I’m a pretty passionate guy when it comes to pizza. I even named my in-game pizzeria after one of the best places I’ve ever had a slice. The game does a nice job of introducing elements at a good clip. It never feels overwhelming, yet there is always a sense of urgency to improve on everything you currently have control over. The actual ‘makin’ pizzas’ part of the game is enjoyable stressful. Maybe it’s the story that makes this a different experience compared to other sim games I’ve tried. It’s bright, a little funny, and a lot endearing. There isn’t much too it, but that feels perfect as the actual management aspects get quite deep. Would I have loved this game as much if it was Hamburger Express? That’s hard to say, but I can say that this game pairs perfectly with a can of pop and your favourite slice.\n

reviewText:
Just a ton of fun. If you liked Cook, Serve, Delicious, you'll probably like this, too. There's an insane amount of customization - difficulty, store decor, advertising, challenge mode options, and most importantly, tons of excellent toppings and doughs - and plenty of side stories and mini-quests to discover. The characters, dialogue, and atmosphere are a delight, too: even the menus have charm. This is one of those games where it feels like the developer thought of everything.

I have to mention my great experience with the developer - in playing through story mode, I hit upon a game-stopping bug. I posted about it on the game's forum, and in less than 24 hours, he'd fixed my save file and put it up on his website for me to download. Considering the he's pretty much running a one-man show, and that Pizza Express has been out a while, the fact that he cheerfully gave me that near-instant one-on-one help is incredibly impressive to me.

I've finished the main story, now, but there's still a lot to do, and I'll be playing this for a while to come.

reviewText:
Holy crap this game sucked me in for several hours.

I really enjoy cooking games, time management games, casual games etc. So when I discovered this little gem, I gave a squee of delight and promptly threw my money at the devs.

I was not disappointed at all. I got to name the pizza shop and make my own recipes. I even got decorating and advertising options! I also really enjoyed the music. That's pretty much it. It's a simple game that is great way to kill time.

My only gripe is that the tutorial system drove me insane. It felt slow and while it was very thorough, I felt like a lot of the things explained were fairly obvious and didn't require walking through. Maybe in a future patch they will swap out the tutorial to a 'Help' section somewhere in the navigational menus.

I think this game is worth the current $6.99 price tag, but I think more people might prefer $4.99.

reviewText:
Highly addictive and fun game, but has a few major flaws...

I am a fan of nice pixel graphics, but this one is not nice about that... Text is sometimes hard to read, and overall visibility is usually low, especially before you get used to it...
Other problem is Lucky, who is JarJar of Pizza Express... Very, very, very irritating character that you want to punch in the face all the time... You can skip the story parts, ofc, but that's not fun...
And the last, but not the least; when you need to spread the dough you use the same click as for sending the pizza into the oven... So, when you accidentally double click, you make a mistake... And it happens a lot, when you are in a rush... Though, I never bothered to look if this can be changed in the options menu xD

Anyway, taking aside these problems; the game is really great, fun and fast! :)

reviewText:
Three weeks ago, I released a preview on a game called Pizza Express. I actually spent a lot of time playing the demo that Onni Interactive very kindly gave to me and I was really enjoying it, so when it was finally released on Steam, I was beyond excited to get my hands on a full copy and attempt to take my pizza palace all the way to the top.

The aim of the game is simple. You’re hired by an anthropomorphic cat named Gastone who recently inherited his father’s old restaurant after it shut down, and his sole desire is to reach the top of the food authority – hilariously named F.L.A.B – best restaurant rankings.  Immediately you’re placed where all the action is, and this is where the majority of the actual playing of the game takes place – the kitchen. Your main task in the game is to provide the public with the pizzas they request in a timely fashion, which sounds easier than it actually is. You have to keep on top of everything more than just the order list, with restocking your toppings being a frequent challenge, as well as managing things like the menu, the amount of tables in the restaurant and even the décor around it. Being able to manage everything to make sure it’s all ticking over correctly and in the most profitable manner can be really fun to tinker about with in order to get the right balance.

Read more at the Video Game Almanac[vgalmanac.com]

reviewText:
Frequent crashes sometimes random crashes on Windows 10. If your wireless 360 controller goes to sleep it'll crash. If you blink sometimes it will crash.

Stupid pixel art that forgets how pixel art was shown back in the day". I like pixel art and enjoy it in most presentations but this is just a bad looking MSpaint game with no charm. More importantly it's a pain to read the text because "back in the day" monitors interlaced with scanlines. Even CRT computer monitors had CRT phosphors and created a high resolution scanline effect.

In short
date: scanlines helped smooth the pixel art so you could freaking read the game
voteText: this game might be purely adequate but it doesn't want me to play long enough to know for sure and honestly the controls may not make me care either way since you have a bunch of short
helpfulPercent: jerking motions with mouse controls it's a RSI nightmare."

reviewText:
Pros:
+ You decide the challenge/reward ratio of pizza making by how you run your place
+ Felt kind of like playing a Harvest moon
+ Nice amount of investment options
+ Cheap game
+ Nice amount of pixel art
+ Good chiptune music
+ Story goes on after each day of working...

Cons:

reviewText:
I wasn't going to get this game until I read the reviews, then I decided to test it out.

Holy ♥♥♥♥, am I ever glad I got this. It's so customizable, so addictive, so colorful. That's all I ever want in a restaurant management simulation, and this nailed it on the head.

reviewText: This game is amazingly fun.  I wish that I could magically have a sea of cash, and take advantage of the high level things.  I'm working my way up there though.  If you like simulation games, you'll love this.  If you like pixels, you'll love this.  If you like chiptune, you'll love this.  Honestly, when I saw this game, I knew that I would love it right away.  It's got a lot of effort and care put into it.  It's as perfect as can be, for the type of game it is.  Very memorable.  Perhaps perfect, if you're a casual gamer.  Of which, I run the gammut.  I just love quirky games, they're just as beautiful as the big budget beasts as far as I'm concerned.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Awesome restaurant management game. I started my culinary career in pizza, and this definitely reminds me of it - sometimes a little too much (in a good way). It's pretty hectic, and each business day can be a relentless wave of clicks as you just barely manage to satisfy all your customers' orders. It can also be a painfully slow day if your menu sucks, or your pricing is off, and too many slow days will spell doom for your pizzeria. As a light simulation, it makes me think in a lot of the same ways as I did in real life about pizzeria work. I would enjoy a little more depth, but the game as it stands now is very accessible and fun.

reviewText: Name the joint, name the pizza, manage the menu/kitchen/advertising/seating/decor/hours, make the pizza in story mode/arcade mode/endurance mode- this is the best pizza-related game steam has to offer!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
As incredible as it may sound, one of the best games I have ever played or ever had in my Steam library. You can feel the passion the developer invested into this game. Pizza Express is a high-quality experience no matter what you are looking for, from arcade , high speed pizza baking, to very detailed and deeply influencial managerial choices.

The controls are very easy, the player only needing a mouse to play, which , sometimes, will move so fast he will feel the difficulty of cooking pizza, hahaha... But for real, the game is as difficult as you want it to be, proving it can quickly become a challenge, no matter how fast you are or how good you are at managing a business.

One of the great aspects of the game are it's characters, which are presented as animals, and are broght to life by the author , which game them a lot of witty dialog lines which will make you feel this guys are your life-time friends, and you will start to catch real feelings about your virtual pizzeria.

I really hope the developer will keep this great game alive or come with a second part, maybe in another domain, because with this passion he put up here I'm sure he can create real masterpieces.

reviewText: Despite this being made in gamemaker (which isn't the most effective engine), this was still an incredibly solid game. Not only that but the soundtrack is pretty amazing. Incredibly appropriate for the style of game provided for us. As far as errors go, I have yet to come across any fatal errors that ruined the game. I mean I'd get an error that would shut down the game every blue moon, but i'd play at the beginning of a new day, whenever the game was already saved. Afterwards I could usually just go back on the game and pick up where I left of.\nGreat game. It's a shame this doesn't get more publicity.

reviewText:
I don't know why, but this game got me hooked right from the start, and I still find it hard to let go.

It's a fun pizza sim game, with great dialogue, characters and overall a good story.
The achievements are many, and some of them are extremely hard to get, but it will keep you even more motivated to get the job done. There are SO many possibilities in this game, and it's so god damn addictive!!!!

The only negative thing I can think of is that awfully annoying tutorial, but you have the possibility to skip it every time you get one at least.

So bottom line, do I recommend this? YES!!!!!

reviewText: Pizza Express is an exceptionally brilliant game / simulation that should be required for every business / MBA student. Balance costs with expenses; manage orders with FIFO and learn the value of just-in-time ordering. Above all, have a blast baking breathtaking pizzas and crushing your competition!
